Anglo-Nubian Goat.description: The Anglo-Nubian goat is a large goat with a Roman nose and pendulous ears that hang low and close to the head. Anglo-Nubian goats are most often black, red, or tan. They are multi-purpose animals bred for milk, meat, and hides. They donâ€™t produce an especially large volume of milk, but their milk is higher in butterfat and more flavorful than that of other breeds.

Boer Goat.description: The Boer breed is characterized by a red head and red on at least a portion of the neck, with a white body. They have large pendulous ears. Boer goats are in high demand because they grow fast, making them desirable in the meat indsutry.

Saanen Goat.description: The Saanen is a delicate-looking goat with a lean body type. They are leggier than most meat breeds of goat which is good for ease-of-milking. Unlike some goat breeds, their hair is soft, short, and smooth and comes in two colors: white and light cream.

Nigerian Dwarf Goat.description: The Nigerian Dwarf goat is a miniature goat from West Africa. Their coats come in many colors, including gold, black, chocolate, and even Dalmation-spotted. They are raised for both milk production and as pets.

Alpine Goat.description: The French-Alpine is variable in size, and can have varying coat colors, including pure white, gray, brown red and black. They are often used for commercial dairy production.

American Pygmy Goat.description: The American Pygmy goat comes in three different colors: Caramel, Agouti, and Black. A full grown American Pygmy goat is roughly the same size as a medium adult dog.

Fainting Goat.description: Despite their name, fainting goats don't actually faint! When startled or excited, their muscles stay tense causing them to stiffen or fall over, though they never lose conciousness.
